learning_outcomes.description: Describe the importance of soils for regulating plant growth, food production, and climate change
Evaluate how soils interact with the broader environment, including their influence on a range of environmental processes
Explain the role of agriculture production systems in the sustainable management of soils
Use soil water relationships to examine plant water use and optimise irrigation systems
Experimentally investigate approaches for solving a range of soil science problems, including for management of soil degradation

assessments.task_description:
Practical assessment is divided into 4 x practical hands-on sessions followed by the preparation of a written practical report.

Each report will be based on specific practical classes. Practical Classes are scheduled every 2-3 weeks. The practicals run for approximately 3 hours and are a combination of laboratory-based and field-based activities. To obtain a mark for the practical classes students must participate and complete the associated exercises (submitting the practical report via Blackboard - Turnitin). If you do not participate in a practical class, or do not provide evidence of your attendance (i.e. signing attendance sheet), your report will not be marked/graded. Refer to late submission notes for more information.

Details about the Practical will be provided within a Practical Manual, which will be made available on Blackboard site before the scheduled practical, with additional specifics about report preparation and report submission.

  • Report 1: Field assessment of soil properties and constraints.

Students will be able to describe a soil profile using field methods to assess the suitability, limitations of the soil and potential of the soil for plant growth and potential land use. This report will assess learning objectives 1, 2 & 5.

  • Report 2: Effects of organic matter on soil properties.

Students will investigate the effect of various organic matter sources on soil properties including respiration and bulk density. This report will assess learning objectives 2, 3 & 5.

  • Report 3: Fertilizer (organic vs inorganic) effects on plant growth.

Students will set up a glasshouse trial comparing the effect of mineral and organic fertilisers on a test crop growth. This report will assess learning objectives 2, 3 & 5.

  • Report 4: Irrigation system design and evaluation.

Students will set up and compare different types of drip irrigation systems to evaluate their advantages and limitations. This report will assess learning objectives 4 & 5.
